hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Kylar broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$542\times6$

We can break apart $542$ into $500 + 40 + 2$ and multiply each part by $6$.

We can start by multiplying $500\times6$ , $40\times6$, or $2\times6$. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
542&\\
\underline{{} \times 6}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
3{,}000\\
240\\
\underline{{}+12}\end{align}\right.\\
&3{,}252
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
\maroonE{5}08&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE{4}}&\\
\maroonE{\phantom{2}{2{,}000}}&\qquad\maroonE{4\times 500}\\
\end{align}$

There are $5$ hundreds in $508$, and $\maroonE{4}\times\maroonE{500}=\maroonE{2{,}000}$. So Kylar did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
5\purpleE{0}8&\\
\underline{{} \times \purpleE{4}}&\\
2{,}000&\quad {4} \times {500} \\
\purpleE{0}&\quad \purpleE{4} \times \purpleE{0\text{ tens}}
\end{align}$

Kylar said that $\purpleE4\times\purpleE{0}$ equals $\purpleE{40}$. So Kylar made a mistake in step $2$.
Kylar made a mistake in step $2$.

question.content:
Kylar tried to evaluate $508\times4$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.

$\begin{align}
&&508 \\
&&\underline{\times\phantom{22}4} \\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 1}}&\maroonE{\phantom{2}{2{,}000}}&\qquad\maroonE{4\times 500}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 2}}&\purpleE{{}\phantom{2} 40} &\qquad\purpleE{4\times 0}\\
&\blueE{\text{Step 3}}\quad&\underline{\blueE{{}+32}}&\qquad\blueE{4\times8}\\
&\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\goldE{2{,}072}& &
 \end{align}$

**Find Kylar's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue: There are $5$ hundreds in $508$, and $\maroonE{4}\times\maroonE{500}=\maroonE{2{,}000}$. So Kylar did not make a mistake in step $1$.
$4\times 0= 0$, not $40$. So Kylar made a mistake in step $2$.
There are $8$ ones in $508$, and $\blueE{4}\times\blueE{8}=\blueE{32}$. So Kylar did not make a mistake in step $3$.
Kylar correctly added his three partial products.
